options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I continued to learn conversational French, including several new tenses, moods, and conjugations.
Learning how to speak French
I learned most of the basic grammar of French and feel ready to improve my skills through attempts to practice reading original French texts and to converse with native speakers.
I praticied speaking french and revised tenses.
Continuation of French L1 by expanding vocabulary and learning the grammatical structure of the language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Capretz Method
Weaknesses: Too disorganized sometimes

The course provided equal amounts of practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing, so I feel like it was very well rounded. I think that in some cases we spent too much time lingering on a specific topic in terms of vocabulary and phrases, which may have been useful for others, but for me, were not necessarily topics that would come up in an instance where I might try speaking French.
The videos used to instruct are strange and the textbooks are very expensive. There is surely a more cost effective way and literally more effective to teach.
Strengths of the course is that it is very rigorous for learning French. You need to understand and speak French in the class, and the homework outside of class was extensive.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: By the nature of learning a language, the experience was simply not as productive over Zoom as it would otherwise have been. Something is lost when there is no body language or real-time feedback to assist in communication. One adjustment which I found successful was the replacement of the final skit with a film presentation. With a skit, it would have been difficult to act and coordinate with other students, but the film presentation was a solo act.
The seminar format helped

It was a small class, so meeting online was easier. I think that classes were run very well for online classes but that there could have been more opportunities for interaction between the students in the class. If there's anything I felt like I was missing, it was the opportunity to try to interact with others, besides my professor, in French.
The tests were blocked by 24 hour time gaps but not midnight to midnight. This was a problem for me as a remote student in a different time zone.

It is tricky to learn a language over Zoom, mostly because there is less opportunity to hear and attempt correct pronunciation of words. I felt that my reading and writing skills exceeded by listening and speaking skills.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As you probably know from taking 110, the French department takes thing quite seriously. This is not a gut language course. You should certainly take this course if you are interested in learning a language, and learning it well. If you put in the effort, you will make significant progress.
Definitely, helps to get you fluent in French
I would recommend this class to someone who wants to learn the basics of French because I feel that it has provided me with a good foundation that I can build on however I choose in the future.
Yes - french is fun

I would recommend this course to students wanting to improve their French. I really feel that I have come out of this course with the improved ability to speak and write in French. The class is engaging and the work, while repetitive, is comprehensive and easy to follow.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Asynchronous class days
